newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK watchdog says Sumitomo unit outside its reach.
newsitem.headline: HK watchdog says Sumitomo unit outside its reach.

text.p: Hong Kong's securities watchdog said on Wednesday Sumitomo Corp's Hong Kong subsidiary, named in a charge against a former star copper trader in Japan, was outside its jurisdiction.

Sumitomo Corp filed a complaint with Tokyo prosecutors on Tuesday, alleging that trader Yasuo Hamanaka fraudulently raised $770 million in 1994 through a Hong Kong subsidiary of Sumitomo in order to cover losses from unauthorised futures deals.

"The subsidiary in question, Sumitomo Corp. (Hong Kong) Ltd, is not registered with the SFC, so it wouldn't be under our jurisdiction," a spokesman for Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) told Reuters.
The SFC had jurisdiction over organisations that were licenced as brokers or dealers with the commission, he said.
While other Sumitomo subsidiaries were registered with the SFC, Sumitomo Corp.(Hong Kong) Ltd was not, he said.
A spokesman at Hong Kong's Independent Commission Against Corruption witheld all comment.
The copper trader was sacked from Sumitomo Corp in June, in connection with $2.6 billion in losses which the company blamed on unauthorised trades.
Japanese prosecutors said on Wednesday they had served a fresh arrest warrant on Hamanaka on suspicion of fraud.

Hamanaka has been in custody in Tokyo since October 22 on forgery charges. A conviction on fraud charges carries a far more serious penalty than forgery under Japanese law -- up to 10 years in jail versus up to five years.
